body_html:
Thx @jart. The main use case to have multiple sessions is in tensorflow serving inference. Each saved model will be loaded and a new session is created. When a model is no longer used, it can be offloaded and the corresponding session is deleted. As in tensorflow/serving#335, multiple people have this use case and see wrong results.

I also modified the multi_session.py to call create_graph in the spawned threads. This still generates corrupted results.

For thread safety of session, I noticed running multiple sessions on CPU using multiple serving threads in C++ has no issues.

When a model is no longer used, it can be offloaded and the corresponding session is deleted. As in tensorflow/serving#335, multiple people have this use case and see wrong results.
I also modified the multi_session.py to call create_graph in the spawned threads. This still generates corrupted results.
For thread safety of session, I noticed running multiple sessions on CPU using multiple serving threads in C++ has no issues.
body:
Thx @jart. The main use case to have multiple sessions is in tensorflow serving inference. Each saved model will be loaded and a new session is created. When a model is no longer used, it can be offloaded and the corresponding session is deleted. As in https://github.com/tensorflow/serving/issues/335, multiple people have this use case and see wrong results.

I also modified the multi_session.py to call create_graph in the spawned threads. This still generates corrupted results.

For thread safety of session, I noticed running multiple sessions on CPU using multiple serving threads in C++ has no issues.
